header: (FR) Keith collects his public pensions while working

key-takeaways.heading: (FR) Key Takeaways
key-takeaways.li1: (FR) Choosing to take your public pensions and retiring from work are two different things.
key-takeaways.li2: (FR) You can delay both of your public pensions.
key-takeaways.li3: (FR) You can take your Canada Pension Plan (CPP) pension and continue contributing to the plan, and earn Post-Retirement Benefits (PRBs).
key-takeaways.li4: (FR) If you are working with higher earnings and have some retirement savings your lifetime CPP pension might matter more than your monthly pension.
key-takeaways.li5: (FR) You can receive more lifetime pension, if you take CPP at age 65 and get PRBs up to age 70.
key-takeaways.li6: (FR) If your higher monthly pension income is more important to you, you can delay taking CPP up to age 70.
key-takeaways.smart-tip: (FR) Smart tip: If you qualify for the Old Age Security (OAS) pension and have low income, you may also get the Guaranteed Income Supplement (GIS). You cannot receive the GIS if you are delaying your OAS pension. People who qualify for the GIS should not wait to apply past age 65.

overview.heading: (FR) Overview
overview.p1: (FR) Keith worked in construction all his life and just accepted a new site job at 60. Keith has some savings, but still plans to work until at least age 70. Keith wants to know what the best strategy for his Canada Pension Plan (CPP), and Old Age Security (OAS) pensions will be.

prb.p2: (FR) This is because you will have to contribute to the plan until age 65 at least. Each year that you work and contribute, you will receive a small new top-up from an additional PRB that will be added to your CPP pension and benefits.

prb-choices.heading: (FR) What are Keith's choices to combine his CPP pension with PRBs?

list.li1: (FR) Choice 1: Take Canada Pension Plan (CPP) pension at age 60 for the lowest monthly pension. Keith will continue working and contributing until age 70 and receive 10 Post-Retirement Benefits (PRBs).
list.li2: (FR) Choice 2: Take CPP pension at age 60 for the lowest monthly pension. Keith will continue working until age 70, but stop contributing at age 65 and receive 5 PRBs.
list.li3: (FR) Choice 3: Take CPP pension at age 65 and continue contributing to the CPP until age 70. This will give Keith 5 PRBs.
list.li4: (FR) Choice 4: Take CPP retirement at age 70 for the highest monthly pension, without PRBs.

cpp-choices.heading: (FR) What are the CPP monthly pensions for these choices?

choices.li1: (FR) Choice 1: Take CPP at 60, contribute to 70.
choices.li2: (FR) Choice 2: Take CPP at 60, contribute to 65.
choices.li3: (FR) Choice 3: Take CPP at 65, contribute to 70.
choices.li4: (FR) Choice 4: Contribute to 70, take CPP at 70.

cpp-choices.description: (FR) This chart shows four choices Keith has for his monthly retirement income. He has two potential sources of income between his CPP pension and his Post-retirement benefits. For all choices, the CPP pensions makes up the most of his monthly income. Taking his CPP at age 70 is the largest amount of monthly income. Taking his CPP at age 65 and continuing to work for 5 years to receive 5 Post-retirement benefits is the smallest amount of monthly income.

smart-tip.content: (FR) Smart tip: Longevity is an important factor when taking your pensions. Most Canadians underestimate how long they'll live, and many are at risk of outliving their savings. On average, Canadians who are age 65 today can expect to live at least another 20 years. In fact, there is about 50% chance that those who go into retirement today will live up to age 90. It's good to have a financial plan for these years of life.

keith-pension-87.heading: (FR) What will be Keith's pension by age 87?
keith-pension-87.p1: (FR) As Keith is still healthy and working, he should plan on living for another 22-25 years (age 87-90) or longer.
keith-pension-87.p2: (FR) Choice 3 was about Keith taking his Canada Pension Plan (CPP) pension at age 65 and contributing to the plan until age 70. He will have his pension monthly income earlier in life and a higher lifetime pension.
keith-pension-87.p3: (FR) Choice 4 was about Keith delaying his CPP pension until age 70. It is also a good option since it gives the highest monthly pension and a high lifetime pension as well.
